Research Design

1.1. Why Conduct Research on Agatha Christie’s Work? In the first lines of his book on Agatha Christie, anticipating possible doubts or perhaps just teasing, York (2007, p.1) provides a plethora of reasons to conduct serious research on her work. Ten years later, Storm (2017, p.1) tackles the same issue in her thorough study of Christie’s first novel in German and Dutch translations. Agatha Christie might be considered a “lowbrow” writer, but she remains one of the best-selling and most translated authors in the history. She has her active fandom1 that includes incoming new generations of admirers who follow and discuss her work. Her original books and their translations are permanently reprinted, and provided in electronic Kindle versions or as audiobooks, which best confirms the lasting interest of the audience and commercial success. To illustrate, Amazon offers the following recent editions of Christie’s works (selection): The Agatha Christie Collection (General Press 2020), (The man in the brown suit (Independently published 2020), Premium Collection (Kindle, Sanctuary Publishing 2020), The Ultimate Collection (Kindle, ACC 2021), The Secret of Chimneys (MysteriousPress.com/Open Road 2021).2 Interestingly, a collection of the most popular works by Christie is available in the form of audiobooks read by the actor Hugh Fraser, known to the audience as Captain Arthur Hastings from the TV adaptations of Poirot stories which will be discussed below. What is more, Christie’s texts are used worldwide for teaching English as a foreign language. The Collins series includes her books in abbreviated and simplified versions, where selected words are underlined and explained in a glossary, the characters are listed and introduced, the cultural background is briefly outlined. The books are accompanied by CDs, as is common practice in the case of handbooks for foreign language teaching. The Man in the Brown Suit and Murder on the Orient Express, are available on YouTube for free, in the programme English through Story: the learner listens to the text read by a native speaker of English and simultaneously follows the subtitles displayed on the screen. In this way Christie’s prose is disseminated among the English learners, reaching those, too, who may otherwise not choose her works for pleasure reading. It is noteworthy that these easy-to-read versions can substitute translations since they may also attract the non-native speakers of English who are not focused on polishing the language but pleased to read in the original format. Christie’s stories were abundantly adopted for comics or graphic novels.3 For instance, there is a series of comic strips by François Rivière (in French and English) that includes (the dates refer to the English editions) And Then There Were None (1996; 2010), Death on the Nile (1997), Secret of Chimneys (2002), The Secret Adversary (2003), Endless Night (2003; 2010), Murder in Mesopotamia (2005; 2009), Murder on the Links (2012), Murder on the Orient Express (2007). Another series, by Marek, contains (in English) Dumb Witness (2009) and Dead Man’s Folly (2011) as well as (in French) Les oiseaux du lac Stymphale [The Stymphalean Birds] (2010) and Le couteau sur la nuque [Lord Edgware Dies] (2012). The original productions are also translated into other languages. For example, quite recently (2020), a series of seven titles was published in Poland, translated into Polish by Paweł Łapin´ski. In addition, Christie’s crime prose steadily inspires computer and video games creators. Some popular stories (the dates refer to the game release) like And Then There Were None, (2000), Peril at End House, (2009), Death on the Nile (2020), The ABC Murders, (2016), Evil under the Sun (2007), to name just a few, are available to the players from the Amazon stores. The abovementioned editions of Christie’s original works and their impact on other creative productions should suffice to confirm the existence of what can be labelled as Christie-industry, even before mentioning the films which reinforce her popularity the most. Importantly, comics, educational editions and games involve a genre change, which contributes to the revision of the very concept of adaptation that was traditionally associated with film (Sanders 2006, p.18) and now covers the whole abovementioned variety of artistic products based on a precursor text, not necessarily literary. The present research is devoted to film adaptations of Christie’s Poirot works. Some novels about his adventures were brought to screen more than once. They all are easily available to the interested audience. Apart from being included in TV programmes in many countries, they can be legally watched, with no expense, on some VOD platforms. The number and variety of the abovementioned facts fully justify the research into Christie’s work as a massive cultural and social phenomenon. As a matter of fact, there are many books about Agatha Christie and her prose (e. g., Rowland 2001; Campbell 2005; York 2007; MacAllister 2001; Escott 2003; Makinen 2006; Bunson 2008; Hack 2009; Hammer 2012; Harkup 2015; Thompson 2015, Bernthal 2016; Mills and Bernthal 2019, Rolls 2022, to name just a few relatively recent ones). However, the question as to why this phenomenon should be scrutinized from the perspective of translation studies is still to be answered. Before this happens, the central figure of the works selected for this research, the detective Hercule Poirot will be introduced; he is not only the cult character of Agatha Christie’s crime fiction, but also the subject of academic investigations, to whom whole books are devoted (e. g., Hart. 1990, Aldridge 2020).

1.2. Hercule Poirot on Pages Detective Hercule Poirot, alongside Miss Marple, is Christie’s flagship character, hero of thirty-three novels and fifty-one short stories. However, the border between a novel and short story seems rather arbitrary. Poirot was introduced in Christie’s debut novel The Mysterious Affair at Styles, as a Belgian immigrant to England during the First World War, a retired policeman aiming at a career as a private detective in Great Britain. His creator endowed him with brilliant intellect that serves him as the major tool in his investigations, where he uses sophisticated examination methods of physical evidence. At the same time, she deprived him of all the features that could otherwise support his attempts: youth, fitness and good looks. On many hundreds of pages that depict him at work, Poirot will have to compensate for those deficiencies. In Styles (p. 16) the narrator describes him as follows:

Poirot was an extraordinary looking little man. He was hardly more than five feet, four inches, but carried himself with great dignity. His head was exactly the shape of an egg, and he always perched it a little on one side. His moustache was very stiff and military. The neatness of his attire was almost incredible. I believe a speck of dust would have caused him more pain than a bullet wound. Yet this quaint dandyfied little man who, I was sorry to see, now limped badly, had been in his time one of the most celebrated members of the Belgian police. As a detective, his flair had been extraordinary, and he had achieved triumphs by unravelling some of the most baffling cases of the day.

The above description is reinforced, complemented and varied in later works. Seeing that “Poirot was busy mopping his grey suit with a minute sponge” in Kidnapped, Captain Hastings observes that “[n]ever was there a dandy such as Hercule Poirot” (p. 5). In Appointment, Sarah King “noted the egg-shaped head, the gigantic moustaches, the dandified appearance and the suspicious blackness of his hair” (p. 500), and Poirot himself admits: “I take everywhere my little shoecleaning outfit. Also, I take a duster. (…) I like to have the appearance soigne´.” (ibid., p. 536). In Hollow, Lady Angkattel still recalls, after years, his “white duck suit, (…) and a pink flower in his buttonhole, and black patent-leather shoes (p.16). He wears these shoes on regular occasions, like the meeting with Miss Bulstrode in Cat, where he is aware of “an insular prejudice that a headmistress might have against aged foreigners with pointed patent leather shoes” (p. 406), but also, as indicated in Appointment, in some places least suitable for these sorts of footwear, like a desert (p. 536). As is mentioned in Hallowe’en, he sticks to his favourite shoes despite the tangible discomfort they cause him (p. 244–245). Poirot likes regular shapes and symmetry. As he puts it in Davenheim “[i]t is really insupportable (…) that every hen lays an egg of a different size!” (p. 23). According to a description in Victory,” [a] certain harmless vanity was a characteristic of Poirot’s and fell into line with his general love of order and method.” (p. 5). The awareness of his own abilities is one of Poirot’s most salient features. As observed by his young friend Colin in Clocks (p. 299), “modesty was certainly not Hercule Poirot’s strong point”. There are multiple references to Poirot’s working methods and working ethos. He proceeds “by methodical sifting of the evidence, by a process of reasoning (…) and by a study of the psychological possibilities.” (Appointment, p. 496). He believes most in the efficiency of logical reasoning of his “grey cells”; in his own word in Links, (p. 8). “the true work, it is done from within. So, in Five (p. 18–190), he warns the young Caroline Crale that his investigations may as well exclude as prove the guilt of her late mother. Similarly, in Cypress (p.143), Doctor Lord, who is desperately trying to save the woman he loves, learns and accepts that Poirot’s examinations may confirm her guilt rather than her innocence. Poirot’s admiration for Countess Rossakoff ’s appearance and her thief ’s skills are mightily exploited in some film adaptations and converted into a deep, lasting affectation that is not founded in any precursor text. In fact, it is only confirmed in Chest, (p. 3) that “[t]here had been a certain Russian countess – but that was long ago now. A folly of earlier days”. Another exception to Poirot’s faithfulness to the truth can be encountered in Orient, where he saves twelve killers from responsibility for their collective act of revenge, keeping the truth about their criminal act to himself. Now and then, Poirot deliberately leaves the door open for the murderer’s suicide, which is the case, for instance, in Ackroyd, where he encourages his friend Doctor Shephard to take poison, and in Nile, where he allows Jacqueline to shoot her beloved Simon before she shoots herself. It is known that he is catholic. In Flood, he prays in a catholic church (p. 312), which is worth memorizing, too, since his Catholicism is exposed by the filmmakers on several occasions. It is a good question to ask if Hercule Poirot, as described in Christie’s immortal works, is a good, friendly person. Some examples of his behaviour allow for doubts in this respect. In Clapham (p. 7), he finds it below his dignity to look for a missing cook, and once he reluctantly accepts – reproached by the client for serving high society only– he still wants to hide this disgraceful commission from his friend and rival, the Scotland Yard inspector Japp (p. 9). His approach, verging on servitude and toadying, constitutes part of his method of winning people’s trust and sympathy, and then the needed information. He believes in the rule that he articulates in Clocks (p. 316): “Let them talk to you. And from their conversation always, somewhere, you will find a clue. Poirot manipulates people, mainly women, first exploring their weaknesses. For instance, he boasts with his invitation to the Royal Court to soften the inaccessible fan of Royals, Mrs Bishop, in Cypress (p. 178), thus gaining her favour immediately. Captain Hastings on Pages and on the Screen Arthur Hastings is introduced as narrator and main character of Christie’s first novel, The Mysterious Affair at Styles (1920), where he appears as a lieutenant of the British Army on sick leave. The reader learns from his narrative in Kidnapped (p. 3) that he was invalided out of the Army and given a recruiting job. As he admits in Styles (p. 18–19), a detective’s work attracts him: I’ve always had a secret hankering to be a detective!’ (…) I came across a man in Belgium once, a very famous detective, and he quite inflamed me. He was a marvelous little fellow. He used to say that all good detective work was a mere matter of method. My system is based on his – though of course I have progressed rather further. He was a funny little man, a great dandy, but wonderfully clever.

In this way, Hercule Poirot is introduced to the reader, without his name being mentioned yet. Hastings starts working for Poirot, who re-enters his life soon, by accident. Unlike Poirot, Hastings is physically strong and fit for combat, and Poirot can always rely on him when it comes to physical confrontation with a criminal, as is the case, for example, in Cheap (p. 15). Hastings is promoted to the rank of captain before being released to civilian life and retains this military rank as a honorific, as dictates British tradition. He is narrator of many short stories of 1923. Hastings meets his future wife on a train, when they both travel from Paris to London in Links (1923) and emigrates with her to Argentina to run a farm. He returns on several occasions, always alone, and joins Poirot in his investigations. However, in the short stories in which he acts as the narrator, Hastings is still a bachelor and obviously Poirot’s employee – even though this professional relation between them is never called by its name directly. Poirot often mocks Hastings’s interest in women as penchant for auburn hair, e. g., in Sin (p.10) and Flat (p. 9).

1.7. Screen Adaptation as Translation Film adaptation is often perceived as a relative of translation (Kittregde and Krauzer, 1979, p. 7; Klein and Parker, 1981, p. 3; Cattrysse 1992, p. 62; Stam 2000, p. 62; Perdikaki 2017, pp. 50–254). With reference to the dictionary definitions of the words ‘adaptation’ and ‘translation’, Cahir (2006, p. 14) argues that it would be more adequate to refer to films based on literary works as translations rather than adaptations. She concludes that what is traditionally called a screen adaptation does not involve any alterations of a given entity (here: the precursor work) to survive (which defines adaptation), but rather means the production of “a materially different entity”. Cattrysse (2014, pp. 47–49) discusses some common features of adaptation and translation, pointing out that they both are (1) context-embedded products of human activity, relying on multiple agents and recipient-oriented, (2) based upon texts and producing texts, (3) irreversible, (4) teleological, (5) governed by equivalence which can be established empirically (6) exposed to judgements by fidelity criterion. Obviously, some of these properties (2, 4 and 5) refer to the process, and others (1, 3 and 6) to the product. Features (1), (3) and (4) are not distinctive since they apply to an infinite multitude of man-made products.

According to this concept, the label text does not only apply to language products, but also to other manifestations of culture that can be interpreted and talked about. 1.8. Strategy versus Technique in Translation and Adaptation In translation studies, translation strategies (or methods) and techniques (or procedures) are sometimes confused. The reason that it happens is, in my opinion, that the same label may be applicable to both, which can be best illustrated through the example of adaptation. In Vinay and Darbelnet (1995) it is discussed as one of the seven translation procedures (alongside borrowing,

In such cases translators must create a new situation that can be considered as being equivalent. Adaptation can, therefore, be described as a special kind of equivalence, a situational equivalence” (ibid., p. 39). In this sense, adaptation is meant as a translational micro-level solution, where a culture-specific phenomenon deemed unfamiliar to the target recipient is substituted with a familiar one. Peter Newmark (1988) locates adaptation among the translation methods (alongside word-for-word translation, literal translation, faithful translation, semantic translation, free translation, idiomatic translation and communicative translation) and describes it as follows: “This is the ‘freest’ form of translation. It is used mainly for plays (comedies) and poetry; the themes, characters, plots are usually preserved, the SL culture converted to the TL culture and the text rewritten” (ibid., p. 40). Obviously, this definition applies to the production of a traditional (target) text that is based on a (source) text without the intention or ambition to recreate all its elements and features. As I argue elsewhere (Harmon 2021), it is necessary to maintain the difference between translation strategy and translation technique, especially in the context of Hejwowski’s (2015, p. 62) recommendation not to deprive the words which function as terms of the meanings that they have in the general language. In its common use, the word strategy refers to a general plan of executing a task whilst a technique is understood as a describable manner of doing something. Therefore: A translation strategy can be described as the translator’s general intention to, for example, focus on the good quality of the target language, maintain as much as possible of the foreign culture or eliminate the original vulgarity. It applies to the whole text, this is to say to the macro-level, unlike the technique that is utilised on a particular spot and thus on the micro-level. As a consequence, from a researcher’s perspective, a translation technique can be identified through a mere comparison of two small parallel excerpts of the original and its translation, whereas a comparative analysis of the whole parallel texts is necessary in order to determine the translator’s strategy, if any. At the same time, it must not be forgotten that translation strategies and techniques were developed for the purposes of what Jakobson (1959) termed interlingual translation and that he also discerned two other types of translation (interlingual and intersemiotic), which have been paid much attention in translation studies recently. Film adaptation has something in common with both intersemiotic and intralingual translation. It is perceived as the former since it converts words into pictures. What it shares with intralingual translation is that it does not primarily involve a foreign audience; the dialogues are mostly based

Agatha Christie about Adaptation In the novel Mrs McGinty’s Dead (1952), a book by a recurrent character of Poirot stories, the crime fiction author Ariadne Oliver, is to be adapted for the stage. On that occasion, a short dispute takes place which elucidates the nature of adaptation. Mrs Oliver is indignant about the intended manipulations of her text. She complains to her friend Poirot: But you’ve no idea of the agony of having your characters taken and made to say things that they never would have said, and do things that they never would have done. And if you protest, all they say is that it’s ‘good theatre.’ That’s all Robin Upward thinks of. Everyone says he’s very clever. If he’s so clever I don’t see why he doesn’t write a play of his own and leave my poor unfortunate Finn alone. He’s not even a Finn any longer. He’s become a member of the Norwegian Resistance movement. (pp. 89–90)

When she tries to resist substantial changes in her main hero and the plot, the playwright argues: It’s not a book, darling, it’s a play. And we’ve just got to have glamour! Method

These emotional observations that Agatha Christie puts in the mouths of her characters tell us a lot about the nature of adaptation, be it for the stage or the screen. First, both the original author and the adaptor fiercely defend their positions. It appears only fair to the original author that the major features of the main character – which, to a large extent, govern the plot in that they entail or exclude certain courses of events – should be preserved in the adaptation, whereas the adaptor has completely different priorities. He is concerned about “good theatre”, in a broadest meaning of this phrase, including what is appreciated by the audience and sells well, but is not the least bothered about fidelity of his creation to its literary prototype. Second, in this dispute, the parties are not equal. Even though dissatisfied with and angry about the playwright’s choices, the author will capitulate, unless she gives up the tempting plan to get her hero on stage. The playwright, who represents the interests of the producer and thus the sponsor of the whole enterprises, is the powerful and winning agent. Third, the skillful playwright, capable of writing an independent play on his own, relies on the published material by a successful author despite her vehement criticism and invites her to cooperation, ready to cope with permanent tension between them because (and possibly only for this reason) her celebrated name alongside the name of her flag fictional character is meant to attract the audience. Fourth, what is missing from the book (for a good reason) and will be added in the adaptation (for another good reason), is romance. Although Mrs Oliver’s character Sven Hjerson, as designed by his creator, indicates no interest in women, a romantic relation will be imposed on him on stage in order to satisfy the audience’s expectations and increase suspense. The adopter considers his product semidetached from the precursor story. He uses this story and its author as a promotion vehicle for his own product, with no obligation to faithfulness, taking the liberty to “correct” whatever he deems unsuitable or add whatever increases the attractiveness of the product. On the few pages of her novel, Agatha Christie outlined a good chunk of adaptation theory.

2.1. Introduction In this part, only the so-called short stories and the corresponding TV episodes are discussed, whereas the whole Part III is devoted to novels and their TV adaptations. This division results from the arguable pre-assumption that a short story provides less material in terms of events and characters depicted, thus enforcing certain strategies which are not necessary in the case of novel adaptations, especially importation and co-option realised through creative additions. The concept of a short story has been subject of literary theory since the beginning of the twentieth century. As pointed out by Matthews, “a true Shortstory is something other and something more than a mere story which is short” (1994/1901, p. 73). Significant contributions to the short story theory are provided, for instance, by O’Connor (1963) and March-Russel (2009). A review of prevailing short story theories is contained in Patea (2012). To what extent short stories “constitute not a form of knowledge but a challenge of knowledge” (Leitch 1989, p. 133) or “the short story remains by its very nature remote from the community – romantic, individualistic, and intransigent” (O’Connor 1976, p. 89) – these are possible research questions for dedicated studies which will not be pursued here. Otherwise, the results might imply that Christie’s Poirot stories, referred to as short stories for their mere brevity, do not, perhaps, deserve this label at all. In this research, the term short story applies to Christie’s works that are published and promoted as such, without discussing the validity of this term in relation to the works under scrutiny.
